#Text=State of the health care system in Sierra Leone critical
#Text=Saturday , December 5 , 2009
#Text=According to Médecins Sans Frontières the health care system in Sierra Leone causes loss of life because the poor cannot afford medical treatment .
#Text=The maternal death rate and the child mortality rate in Sierra Leone are the highest in the world .
#Text=Experiences of Médecins Sans Frontières had shown that free care or low fees lead to a dramatic increase in the number of patients .
#Text=Nonetheless the national health system of Sierra Leone demands payment for all treatment with simple consultations costing as much as 25 days of income .

#Text=According to Action Against Hunger the number of children with acute malnutrition has reached almost twice the level of the WHO ' s emergency threshold of 2 % in the Moyamba district of Sierra Leone .

#Text=The Los Angeles Times writes that Sierra Leone , in spite of decades of foreign aid , has not yet increased the standard of living of its people considerably and 60 % of the public spending of Sierra Leone come from other governments and nonprofit organizations .
#Text=Since 2002 the country received $ 1 billion in aid but the infant mortality rate is almost the highest in the world , lower than Angola but higher than Afghanistan .

#Text=The newspaper further reports that the United Nations state that 1 in 8 Sierra Leonean women die giving birth , as compared to 1 in 4,800 in the United States and that life expectancy in Sierra Leone is merely 41 years while in Bangladesh life expectancy reaches 60 years .

#Text=The government of Sierra Leone had expressed its intend to abolish user fees for women and children with a new plan for a fairer health care system that was to be revealed on the Sierra Leone Investment and Donor Conference , which was held in London on November 18 and 19 .

#Text=“ The Sierra Leone government has publicly stated its commitment to abolish user fees , and the UK government and other donors have promised to help , ” said Seco Gerard , advisor at Médecins Sans Frontières ’s analysis and advocacy unit .
#Text=“ What is crucial now is that Sierra Leone actually receives the necessary funding and technical assistance to realise this objective .
#Text=It is time that words are being followed up by concrete action .
#Text=If not , people who could otherwise be saved will continue to die needlessly every day . ”
#Text=The Telegraph reports that president Bai Koroma was also hoping to secure a significant increase in aid donations with his new health plan .

#Text=While Germany declined to support president Bai Koroma ’s " Agenda for Change " and urged to give more consideration to women 's welfare the country received support from the European Union , DFID , UNIPSIL , World Bank , IFAD and the African Development Bank .
#Text=From the pledges of $ 850 million the government of Sierra Leone was hoping for only about $ 300 millions could be secured , with attached conditionalities concerning the use of funding .

#Text=In a presentation at the Ministry of Finance and Economic Development in Freetown the Unicef representative for Sierra Leone , Mr. Mahimbo Mdoe , expressed gratitude about a pledge of about $ 1.3 million conveyed by the Ambassador of Japan to Sierra Leone , His Excellency Mr. Keiichi Katakami , and about earlier donations to UNICEF-Sierra Leone in the past years , amounting to over $ 20 million .

#Text=The intended application of the funding is the goal to half child and maternal mortality by 2010 , to introduce a social health insurance scheme , to improve equipment and to train health professionals .
